I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

1. 
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on proposed equity 
investments in climatech venture capital funds of (i) up to $20 million (or the equivalent in Euro) 
in Aloe Environment Fund III (Aloe Fund), (ii) up to $20 million in Keytone Ventures II (Keytone 
Fund)  in the  People’s  Republic  of  China,  and  (iii)  up to $20  million  in VenturEast  Life  Fund III 
(VenturEast  Fund)  in  India,  in  each  case  not  to  exceed  25%  of  the  total  commitments  with 
respect  to the  fund  and  not  resulting  in  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  being  the  largest 
investor in the fund. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 

II. 

BACKGROUND AND RATIONALE 

2. 
The proposed equity investments comprise the equity component of ADB’s Asia Climate 
Change  and  Clean  Energy  Venture  Capital  Initiative,  which  seeks  to  enhance  the  availability 
and  affordability  of  technologies  that  address  climate  change  mitigation  and  adaptation,  and 
environmental protection (hereinafter referred to as ―climatech‖),1 as well as energy security, in 
Asia.2  Through this initiative, ADB proposes to invest $60 million of equity in aggregate in three 
venture  capital  funds,  which  were  selected  through  a  competitive  process.    These  funds  will 
target  early-stage  climatech  ventures  operating  in  ADB’s  developing  member  countries 
(DMCs).3  The initiative will help to facilitate technology innovation, transfer, and diffusion, which 
is  identified  as  one  of  they  key  building  blocks  to  effecting  the  international  climate  change 
agenda as reflected in the Kyoto Protocol, 2007 Bali Action Plan, the Copenhagen Accord, and 
subsequent  agreements.    The  initiative  is  also  expected  to  establish  (through  separate  Board 
approval) a technical assistance (TA) program to provide knowledge support to various funds in 
ADB’s DMCs (potentially including these three) on emerging market opportunities, technological 
competence and growth potential of investee companies, and intellectual property rights issues, 
so that they can allocate more of their fund resources to early-stage companies that lack access 
to  capital,  and  to  those  technologies  that  contribute  greatly  to  climate  change  mitigation  and 
adaptation.  
 
A. 

Economic and Sector Background 
Energy  consumption  in  many  of  ADB’s  DMCs  is  growing  extremely  rapidly,4  raising 
3. 
concerns about the region’s vulnerability to resulting environmental degradation and fluctuations 
                                                
1   Climatech  is  a  term  used  to  encompass  the  broad  spectrum  of  technologies  that  relate  not  only  to  clean 
technology,  but  to  all  technologies  related  to  climate  change  and  the  environment.    Climatech  includes  a  broad 
range of technologies, such as:  (i) supply-side technologies related to renewable energy production and demand-
side technologies related to energy efficiency (i.e. the ―cleantech‖ subset); (ii) non-energy related climate change 
mitigation technologies (such as those related to waste management, fertilizer production, and refrigeration); and 
(iii)  climate  change  adaptation  technologies  (such  as  fresh  water  supply,  flood  protection  equipment,  agriculture 
products,  and  health  care  products  for  treatment  of  climate  change-induced  and/or  exacerbated  vector-borne 
diseases).    The  funds  invested  in  through  the  initiative  are  anticipated  to  invest  more  than  67%  of  aggregate 
commitments in companies primarily related to technologies included within the climatech rubric.   

2   The initiative refers to the identification and investment process for climatech  venture capital funds resulting from 
these equity investments and the complementary TA.  It could potentially  be extended via a second stage of the 
Initiative,  if  ADB  identifies  funds  with  potential,  which  are not  ready  for  investment  now,  but  to  which  ADB  might 
commit in the future if the fund managers mature adequately.   

3   The term ―early-stage technology company‖ refers to an entity that has not yet reached a level of profitability on an 
annual  basis.    Although  these  requirements  will  have  some  flexibility,  approximately  75%  of  a  fund’s  invested 
capital is expected to be invested in early-stage technology companies for funds investing in the PRC and India.  
Where  funds  are  investing  in  other  DMCs,  approximately  50%  of  a  fund’s  invested  capital  is  expected  to  be 
invested in early-stage technology companies. 

4   According  to  the  United  States  Department  of  Energy,  strong  economic  growth  in  the  PRC  and  India  may  push 
their share of world energy consumption to 28% by 2030, a two-fold increase since 2006. The demand for clean 
and  energy-efficient  products  will  expand  along  with  energy  usage.  According  to  DnB  NOR  Markets  Equity 
Research, power generation in the PRC and India together is predicted to be about 46% of the total photovoltaic 
generation in the world in 2030. Similar predictions for wind power in these countries are only slightly less dramatic, 
at nearly 39% of world capacity.   

 2 

in energy  prices,  both  of  which often  hurt the  poor  the  most.  An  important  means of  assisting 
developing countries in mitigating climate change and enhancing energy security is to improve 
the  availability  and  affordability  of  new  low-carbon  technologies.  For  this  to  happen,  however, 
financing must be made available for climate change-related innovation. This entails a need to 
mobilize  private  capital,  as  public  resources  will  be  insufficient  to  finance  innovation  on  the 
required scale.5 To that end, venture capital is one form of financing that could play a vital role in 
meeting this need for investment, however it also is undercapitalized. In view of this, ADB has 
launched  the  equity  component  of  the  initiative.  It  aims  to  invest  equity  into  multiple  funds  to 
accelerate the transfer and diffusion of climate change and environmental technologies via the 
investments the funds will make into climatech portfolio companies. 
 
4. 
 In  addition  to  the  equity  investments,  the  initiative  is  expected  to  establish  a  capacity 
development TA facility, for which separate ADB Board approval will be sought by the Regional 
and  Sustainable  Development  Department  (RSDD).  The  purpose  of  the  proposed  TA  is  for 
ADB’s  DMCs  to  develop  subsectors  within  their  climatech  industry  that  need  support  in 
attracting more active participation of the fund managers. Specifically, the TA will retain a pool 
of  experts  to  provide  advice  as  requested  on  various  aspects  of  the  technology  development 
cycle (e.g. research and development, production, intellectual property rights) especially in sub-
sectors  within  the  climatech  industry  where  ADB’s  DMCs  may  not  have  active  participation  of 
fund managers, or where fund managers lack expertise. These experts, available on demand, 
are  expected  to  provide  support6  in  identifying  potential  investees  and  evaluating  new 
technologies  and  subsectors.  The  TA  will  coordinate  closely  with  the  regional  departments  of 
ADB  to  identify  potential  large-scale  deployment  opportunities  for  promising  climatech 
applications.  
 
 By embracing the ingenuity of the private sector in developing low-carbon technologies 
5. 
and products that might not otherwise make it to the market, ADB believes that the  initiative—
with its equity and knowledge components—can help  DMCs address a number of severe public 
problems,  such  as climate  change,  environmental  degradation,  energy  security,  and  pollution-
related  health concerns.  In the  process, these efforts  could offer  a boost  to a possible growth 
sector,  thereby  creating  employment  opportunities,  reducing  poverty,  and  spurring  economic 
growth. 
 
B. 
 
6. 
Regulatory  status.  The  three  funds  proposed  for  investment  will  primarily  target  the 
markets  of  the  PRC  and  India.  Given  the  institutional  environment  for  business  development 
and  venture  capital  fund  operations,  and  the  market  conditions  in  the  sectors  targeted  by  the 
venture  capital  funds,  both  the  PRC  and  India  are  environments  conducive  to  allowing  the 
growth and success  of  climatech  venture  capital.  Policy  interventions  are  essential  in creating 
an environment within which climatech can effectively compete. The governments of the three 
funds’  target  countries  are  actively  developing  mechanisms  to  stimulate  clean  energy  and 
sustainable technologies.7 (Appendix 2 provides information on the investment environment and 
government policies for climatech venture capital investing in the PRC and India.) 

Investment Environment and Government Policy  

 
 

                                                
5   Recent  estimates  indicate  that  the  mitigation  financing  needs  of  developing  countries  will  grow  to  well  over  
$100  billion  per  year  by  2020,  depending  on  how  ambitious  the  greenhouse  gas  emission  reductions  goals  are. 
The corresponding estimates for adaptation costs range from $75 billion to $100 billion per year. 

6 The primary aim of the TA is to develop the climatech sector in the DMCs – to the benefit of many funds, not just the 
three being proposed for investment at this time.  Indeed, the selected fund managers already have the basic skills 
needed for climatech investment assessment in-house.  However, to the extent that the fund managers of funds 
proposed in this equity investment have gaps in climatech sector expertise, the fund managers may avail of the TA.  
7   RSDD  has  funded  a  consultant  to  research  the  investment  environments  and  government  policies  in  these 

countries, and the related research paper is available as a supplemental appendix.   

 C. 

Alignment with ADB Strategy and Operations  

7. 
The  CFP  and  consequent  selection  of  funds  are  broadly  aligned  with  ADB’s  Strategy 
20208  and  climate  change  priorities,  as  well  as  the  energy  sector  strategies  of  ADB  and  the 
DMCs targeted by the three proposed funds.   
 

1. 

Consistency with Strategy 2020 

8. 
The funds selected through the CFP will make venture capital investments in climatech 
companies and projects in ADB’s DMCs. As such, these fund investments are fully aligned with 
ADB’s Strategy 2020, which has enshrined the environment, including climate change, as one 
of  its  five  core  operational  priorities.  Furthermore,  the  objective  of  the  climatech  investments 
made by the three proposed funds is to address climate change and the environment through 
development and transfer of technologies. This aligns well with Strategy 2020’s promotion of the 
use  of  environment-friendly  technologies,  and  its  focus  on  transfer  of  knowledge  and 
technologies on environmental management. 
 

2. 

Consistency with ADB’s Climate Change Priorities   

9. 
The  initiative  is  proposed  to  be  implemented  as  part  of  ADB's  emphasis  on  climatech 
technology transfer and diffusion, efforts that were strongly backed by the President's Advisory 
first  meeting  on  
Group  on  Climate  Change  and  Sustainable  Development 
1 September 2009. To that end, ADB's realigned strategic agenda surrounding climate change, 
embodied in the Addressing Climate Change in Asia and the Pacific: Priorities for Action paper 
approved by the President on 27 April 2010, specifically states that ADB will move upstream in 
the  technology  development  process,  in  collaboration  with  governments,  venture  funds,  and 
other partners, to facilitate the introduction of new clean energy technologies.  
 

its 

in 

3. 

Consistency with the Sector and Country Strategies 

The  investments  in  the  three  proposed  funds  are  aligned  with  ADB’s  Energy  Policy 
10. 
(2009), which seeks to facilitate a transition to a low-carbon economy and universal access to 
energy  as  an  important  step  toward  achieving  ADB’s  vision  of  a  region  free  of  poverty.9  The 
country partnership strategies (CPSs) for various DMCs (including the PRC and India, the two 
main target DMCs for the three proposed funds) echo the themes of the Energy Policy, setting 
targets for more environment-friendly energy mixes to improve energy security and ensure the 
sustainability of economic progress.   
 

4. 

Lessons from Previous Operations 

11. 
Incubating  funds  takes  time  and  effort.  ADB  has  learned  lessons  from  its  past 
investments in five clean energy funds approved in 2008, four of which are now operating. ADB 
provided  extended  assistance  to  these  funds  over  2  years  for  incubation  activities  and 
fundraising.  Because  the  funds  faced  many  challenges,  ADB’s  consistent  commitment  and 
support  was  critical  to  their  ultimate  success  in  reaching  financial  closure.  The  lesson  drawn 
from  this  experience  was  that  a  great  deal  of  time  and  effort  is  needed  to  incubate  first-time 
emerging  market  funds  in  an  ongoing  challenging  fundraising  environment,  and  ADB  should 
make  a  deliberate  choice  regarding  projects  where  this  expenditure  of  time  and  effort  is 
warranted.   
 
 

                                                
8  ADB.  2008.  Strategy  2020:  The  Long-Term  Strategic  Framework  of  the  Asian  Development  Bank,  2008–2020.

3 

 

 4 

12. 
In  entering  new  markets  or  asset  classes,  established  managers  are  safer 
partners. Because it drew such a large volume of proposals, the CFP provided ADB the luxury 
of choice among established climatech venture capital fund managers in the PRC and India. As 
a  way  to  mitigate  the  risk  associated  with  an  asset  class  that  is  both  relatively  risky  and 
relatively  new  for  ADB,  ADB  selected  three  of  the  highest  caliber  and  most  experienced  fund 
managers  that  submitted  proposals.  None  is  a  first-time  manager,  and  all  three  have 
successfully raised funds (for two of the three managers, multiple funds). Two of the three funds 
are  well  along  in  the  fundraising  process,  and  all  three  have  established  track  records  in 
climatech investing. These three managers are seen as the most commercially viable managers 
available  in  the  market  at  this  time,  and  this  is  viewed  as  an  appropriate  starting  point  for 
gaining exposure to a relatively new asset class.10 
 
D. 

Development Impact 

13. 
Project  outputs  and  outcome.  The  key  output  of  ADB’s  investment  will  be  the 
establishment  and/or  funding  of  the  selected  venture  capital  funds,  enabling  their  financing  of 
technology  start-up  businesses  focusing  on  climate  change  mitigation  and  adaptation,  and 
environmental  protection,  in  the  DMCs.  The  fund  investments  in  climatech  companies  and 
projects, and the fund managers’ ongoing management advice to those investees, will increase 
access  to  finance  and  expertise  for  climatech  companies  and  projects  in  the  target  regions 
(outcome).  
 
14. 
Impact.  The  ultimate  development  impact  of  the  proposed  investments  will  be 
accelerated innovation and diffusion of climate change mitigation and adaptation technologies, 
and environmental protection technologies, which will serve to make them more competitive and 
affordable in developing Asia. 
 

III. 

THE FINANCIAL INTERMEDIARIES  

A. 

Aloe Environment Fund III 

1. 

Sponsor and Ownership 

 
15. 
Aloe Environment Fund III (Aloe Fund) will be established as a Mauritius company. The 
general  partner  will  be  Green  Investment  Group,  and  the  fund  manager  will  be  Aloe  Private 
Equity, an established venture capital investment group and a pioneer in clean energy investing, 
with expertise in transferring technologies from developed countries to the high-growth markets 
of Asia. Aloe Private Equity has operated since 2003, having managed two prior funds (plus a 
third parallel fund established specifically for development finance institutions), and was one of 
the earliest investors in environmental sustainability  in the PRC and India. Aloe Private Equity 
has offices in Beijing, London, Mumbai, and Paris.   
 

2. 

Governance Structure 

a. 

Management  

The  fund  manager  will  be  responsible  for  originating,  structuring,  and  negotiating 
16. 
transactions;  making  recommendations  to  Aloe  Fund’s  general  partner  with  regard  to  the 
acquisition  and  disposition  of  portfolio  investments;  monitoring  portfolio  investments;  and 
assisting  in  the  administration  of  capital  calls  and  distributions  to  investors,  and  investor 
reporting.  The  senior  management  team,  which  has  operated  together  for  7  years,  includes 
                                                
10  Incubation of new funds is an appropriate role for ADB in circumstances where, for example, ADB wants to help 
develop  a  new  asset  class  in  which  few  managers  exist  and  ADB  does  not  have  the  luxury  of  choice  among 
established  managers.  This  was  the case  for  this  CFP  with  regard  to particular  geographies, such  as  Southeast 
Asia; in these regions, ADB may choose to incubate a climatech fund.   

 individuals  whose  backgrounds  combine  engineering  and  operating  experience  and  clean 
technology domain knowledge, along with a track record in venture capital in Asia and Europe 
and in clean technology transfer from developed markets to developing markets.  

 

 

b. 

Corporate Governance 

Aloe  Fund  will  have  an  advisory  committee  comprised  of  five  members,  including  two 

17. 
representatives of the fund manager and three investors, including ADB.   
 

c. 

Risk Management  

Aloe  Private  Equity  will  manage  risk  through  its  investment  process,  which  involves 

18. 
multiple steps and, in addition to the vote of the formal investment committee.  
 

3. 

Business Overview and Strategy 

a. 

Investment Objectives 

 
19. 
Aloe  Fund’s  main  objective  is  to  leverage  its  deep  climatech  sector  knowledge  to 
generate  attractive  financial  returns  by  making  venture  capital  investments  in  companies 
working  to  sustain,  restore,  and  improve  the  global  environment;  and  to  reduce,  reuse,  and 
recycle natural resources. Aloe Fund will invest in Asian companies whose technologies can be 
applied  to  the  markets  of  the  PRC,  India,  and,  potentially,  countries  in  Southeast  Asia.  The 
fund’s  focus  is  to  develop  relationships  between  portfolio  companies  and  their  Asian-based 
partners with a particular emphasis on transferring technology and know-how.  
 

b.   

Investment Strategy 

 
20. 
Aloe  Fund  seeks  to  actively  assemble  and  build  scalable  climatech  manufacturing 
business  models,  built  around  proven  climatech  technology  transferred  from  the  west,  which 
can  be  adapted  to  the  local  environment  in  Asia.  Its  focus  sectors  include  clean  energy 
(biomass, biofuels, solar, wind, small hydro, transportation); waste recycling (plastics, batteries, 
electrical waste, metals, paper); and eco-processes (resource-saving equipment and processes, 
environment-friendly air and water treatment), all of which have a large-scale positive impact on 
greenhouse gas emission reductions and a cleaner, safer environment. The fund’s patient, long-
term investment approach focuses specifically on transferring clean technologies (from Europe 
or other parts of the world) to early-stage companies in the clean technology sector in Asia.  
 
B. 

Keytone Ventures II 

1. 

Sponsor and Ownership 

21. 
Keytone Ventures II (Keytone Fund) will be a Cayman Islands exempted limited liability 
partnership. The general partner and fund manager will be Keytone Capital Partners II (Keytone 
or  Keytone  Ventures),  a  Cayman  Islands  limited  partnership.    Formerly  the  Kleiner  Perkins 
Caufield  &  Byers  China  Beijing  team,  Keytone  is  an  experienced,  well-known,  and  respected 
investment group that has operated since 2008. Keytone Fund seeks to replicate the strategy of 
its fully-invested  $200  million  Keytone  Ventures  Fund  I,  which engaged  in disciplined  venture-
style  investing,  targeting  early-growth  companies  in  clean  technology,  technology,  and  the 
consumer and media sectors in the PRC with manageable risks and venture-like returns.  

 
 

 

5 

 

 6 

 

2. 

Governance Structure 

a. 

Management  

Keytone  Fund 

is  managed  by  Keytone  Ventures.  Keytone  Fund’s 

22. 
investment 
management team will be responsible for originating, structuring, and negotiating transactions; 
making recommendations to Keytone Fund’s general partner with regard to the acquisition and 
disposition  of  portfolio  investments;  monitoring  portfolio  investments;  and  assisting  in  the 
administration  of  capital  calls  and  distributions  to  investors,  and  the  preparation  of  reports  for 
investors.  The  management  team  will  comprise  individuals  whose  backgrounds  combine 
knowledge  of  clean  technology,  technology,  and  consumer  and  media  domain,  along  with 
international and local venture investment and operating experience.  
 

b. 

Corporate Governance 

Keytone Fund will have an advisory board comprising representatives of limited partners 

23. 
designated by the general partner. ADB will have a seat on the advisory board. 

c. 

Risk Management  

24. 
The  fund  manager  will  manage  risk  through  its  investment  process,  which  involves 
several  layers  of  approval,  and  through  its  investment  committee.  The  investment  committee 
comprises  members  with  extensive  experience  in  technology  and  venture  capital  investment 
management. 
 

3. 

Business Overview and Strategy 

a. 

Investment Objectives 

 
25. 
Keytone  Fund  seeks  to  replicate  the  proactive  investment  strategy  applied  in  its  first 
fund,  which  is  to  invest  primarily  in  early-stage  companies  in  the  cleantech,  technology,  and 
consumer and media sectors in the PRC. This sector focus reflects Keytone’s collective areas of 
strength and what the Keytone team believes are potentially the most lucrative sectors offering 
promising  investment  opportunities,  driven  by  growing  spending  power  and  technological 
innovations.       
 

b.   

Investment Strategy 

 
Keytone  Fund  intends  to  follow  an  initiative-driven  investment  approach  where  the 
26. 
Keytone team will actively seek business opportunities along a given industry’s value chain and 
endeavor  to  identify  the  best  companies  to  capture  such  opportunities.  Keytone  will  make 
investments  primarily  in  early-  and  early-growth-stage  companies  that  have  implemented 
product or business models, and that present reasonable visibility to become industry leaders.  
 
C. 

VenturEast Life Fund III 

1. 

Sponsor and Ownership 

27. 
VenturEast  Life  Fund  III  (VenturEast  Fund)  is  part  of  VenturEast’s  fund  family, 
comprising $170 million of assets under management, including two life science funds and two 
technology  funds  in  India,  all  of  which  focus  on  venture-style  investing.  VenturEast  Fund’s 
investment advisor is VenturEast Mauritius Investment Advisors, which will manage VenturEast 
Fund,  and  will  in  turn  appoint  APIDC  Venture  Capital,  a company  incorporated  in  India,  as its 
subadvisor  (VenturEast  Mauritius  Investment  Advisors  and  APIDC  Venture  Capital  jointly 
referred to as VenturEast). VenturEast Fund will invest pro rata alongside a parallel investment 

 trust,  based  in  India,  for  domestic  investors;  however,  this  structure  will  be  converted  into  a 
unified  fund  structure  subject  to  regulatory  approval.  Together,  the  international  and  domestic 
funds are targeting $200 million.    
 

2. 

Governance Structure 

a.

a. 

Investment Objectives 

31. 
VenturEast Fund seeks to leverage the fund manager’s life sciences platform and global 
network  of  leading  life  science  technology  investors,  and  the  management  team’s  experience 
making venture-style investments in these sectors, to identify and invest in life sciences-driven 
clean  environment,  sustainable  agriculture,  and  health-care  businesses  in  India.  The  fund 
manager will focus on investing in companies that seek to apply proven technologies from other 
regions, or scale up business models from other regions, in the Indian market. 
 

b. 

Investment Strategy 

 
32. 
VenturEast  Fund  expects  to  invest  its  committed  capital  in  health  care,  sustainable 
agriculture,  and  clean  environment.  However,  half  of  the  deals  in  health  care  and  sustainable 
agriculture  will  also  fall  within  the  parameters  of  climatech,  as  they  will  have  a  measurable 
impact on reducing greenhouse gas emissions. VenturEast Fund targets companies in India in 
climatech  subsectors  that  contribute  to  a  cleaner,  safer  environment,  including  companies 
focusing  on  efficiency  improvement,  waste  management,  and  clean  water  production.  It  will 
generally  invest  in  rapidly  growing  companies  at  the  postrevenue,  proof  of  application,  or 
business model stage (which would often be preprofit). They plan to seek business models that 
include  capitalizing  on  reengineered  product  innovations,  deploying  in  India  technologies 
derived from developed markets, or seeking to adapt existing business models from developed 
markets in the Indian context.

BACKGROUND AND RATIONALE—SUPPLEMENTAL INFORMATION 

1. 
 The  proposed  equity  investments  comprise  the  equity  component  of  the  Asia  Climate 
Change and Clean Energy Venture Capital Initiative of the Asian Development Bank (ADB). The 
initiative seeks to enhance the availability and affordability of technologies that address climate 
change  mitigation  and  adaptation,  and  environmental  protection  (hereinafter  referred  to  as 
climatech),12 as well as energy security in Asia.13 Through this initiative, ADB proposes to invest 
$60 million of equity in aggregate in three venture capital funds, which were selected through a 
competitive process. These funds will target early-stage climatech ventures operating in ADB’s 
developing member countries (DMCs).14 The initiative will help facilitate technology innovation, 
transfer, and diffusion, which is identified as one of they key building blocks to implementing the 
international climate change agenda reflected in the Kyoto Protocol, 2007 Bali Action Plan, the 
Copenhagen  Accord,  and  subsequent  agreements.  The  initiative  is  also  expected  to  establish 
(through  separate  approval  of  the  ADB  Board  of  Directors)  a  complementary  technical 
assistance  (TA)  program  to  provide  knowledge  support  to  various  funds  (potentially  including 
these three) on emerging market opportunities, technological competence and growth potential 
of investee companies, and intellectual property rights issues, so that they can allocate more of 
their  fund  resources  to  early-stage  companies  that  lack  access  to  capital,  and  to  those 
technologies that contribute greatly to climate change mitigation and adaptation.      
 
A. 

Economic and Sector Background 

2. 
Climate  change  and  energy  security.  As  the  world  continues  to  forge  a  new  regime 
beyond  the  end  of  the  first  commitment  period  of  the  Kyoto  Protocol  in  2012,  Asia  and  the 
Pacific  has  become  a  major  participant  in  the  global  climate  change  agenda.  Energy 
consumption  in  many  of  the  DMCs  is  growing  extremely  rapidly.15  Although  their  per  capita 
emissions remain far lower than those of the developed world, many of these DMCs, with their 
large  populations,  fast  urbanization,  and  rapidly  growing  economies,  have  now  joined  the 
world’s  largest  emitters  of  greenhouse  gases  (GHGs).  The  region  is  highly  vulnerable  to  the 
negative  impacts  of  climate  change,  with  more  people  at  risk  than  in  any  other  region  of  the 
world. Proactive efforts to mitigate the causes of global warming (mitigation) and help the most 
vulnerable  communities  adapt  to  the  impacts  of  climate  change  (adaptation),  while  helping  to 
curtail  environmental  degradation,  are  vital  to  continued  poverty  reduction  and  inclusive 

                                                
12  Climatech  is  a  term  used  to  encompass  the  broad  spectrum  of  technologies  that  relate  not  only  to  clean 
technology,  but  to  all  technologies  related  to  climate  change  and  the  environment.  Climatech  includes  a  broad 
range of technologies, such as (i) supply-side technologies related to renewable energy production and demand-
side  technologies  related  to  energy  efficiency  (i.e.,  the  cleantech  subset);  (ii)  non-energy-related  climate  change 
mitigation technologies (such as those related to waste management, fertilizer production, and refrigeration); and 
(iii)  climate  change  adaptation  technologies  (such  as  fresh  water  supply,  flood  protection  equipment,  agriculture 
products,  and  health  care  products  for  treatment  of  climate  change-induced  and/or  exacerbated  vector-borne 
diseases).  The  funds  invested  in  through  the  initiative  are  anticipated  to  invest  more  than  67%  of  aggregate 
commitments in companies primarily related to technologies included within the climatech rubric.   

13  The initiative refers to the identification and investment process for climatech  venture capital funds resulting from 
these  equity  investments  and  the  complementary  TA.  It  could  potentially  be  extended  via  a  second  stage  of  the 
initiative if ADB identifies funds with potential, but which are not ready for investment, to which ADB might commit 
in the future if the fund managers mature adequately.   

14  The term ―early-stage technology company‖ refers to an entity that has not yet reached profitability on an annual 
basis.  Although  these  requirements  will  have  some  flexibility,  approximately  75%  of  a  fund’s  invested  capital  is 
expected  to  be  invested  in  early-stage  technology  companies  for  funds  investing  in  the  PRC  and  India.  Where 
funds  are  investing  in  other  DMCs,  approximately  50%  of  a  fund’s  invested capital  is  expected  to  be  invested in 
early-stage technology companies. 

According to the United States Department of Energy, strong economic growth in the People’s Republic of 
China  and  India  may  push  their  share  of  world  energy  consumption  to  28%  by  2030,  a  two  fold  increase  since 
2006. The demand for clean and energy-efficient products will expand along with energy usage. According to DnB 
NOR Markets Equity Research, power generation from photovoltaics in the People’s Republic of China and India 
together is predicted to be about 46% of the total photovoltaic generation in the world in 2030. Similar predictions 
for wind power in these countries are only slightly less dramatic, at nearly 39% of world capacity.

economic growth in the region. A related and mounting global concern is energy security. Asia

Need  for 

investment 

 
3. 
Need  for  dissemination  of  climatech  solutions.  An  important  means  of  assisting 
developing countries in mitigating climate change and enhancing energy security is to improve 
the  availability  and  affordability  of  new  low-carbon  technologies,  which  can  help  countries 
leapfrog the carbon-intensive phase of development that most developed countries experienced 
over  the  past  century,  and  move  directly  to cleaner  and more  advanced  energy  solutions with 
lower GHG emissions. Transfer and diffusion of technology is one of the main pillars of the 2007 
Bali  Action  Plan,  a  landmark  document  that  calls  for  long-term  cooperative  actions  beyond 
2012.  The  2009  Copenhagen  Accord  took  the  Bali  Action  Plan  further  by  proposing  the 
establishment of a mechanism to ―accelerate technology development and transfer in support of 
action on adaptation and mitigation.‖16 
 
into  climate  change  mitigation  and  adaptation,  and 
4. 
environmental protection. The investment required to address climate change mitigation and 
adaptation  and  environmental  protection,  through  (among  other  means)  the  provision  and 
dissemination of new low-carbon technologies, is enormous. Recent estimates indicate that the 
mitigation financing needs of developing countries will grow to well over $100 billion per year by 
2020, depending on how ambitious the GHG emission reductions goals are. The corresponding 
estimates  for  adaptation  costs  range  from  $75  billion  to  $100  billion  per  year.  Indeed,  vast 
opportunities  are  emerging  for  businesses  to  benefit  as  early  movers  in  climate  change  and 
environmental technologies (i.e., climatech), and to capitalize on the substantial policy support 
that  exists  within and from  outside  Asia  for  the  region to transition  to  low-carbon and climate-
resilient growth. Beginning in the early 2000s, climbing fuel prices and growing public demand 
for  reducing  energy  costs  and  addressing  climate  change  led  to  a  convergence  of  social, 
political,  economic,  environmental,  and  entrepreneurial  forces  that  are  collectively  driving  the 
development of a broad-based climatech industry. For the sector to flourish, however, financing 
must  be  made  available  for  climate  change-related  innovation;  this  entails  a  need  to  mobilize 
private  capital,  as  public  resources  will  be  insufficient  to  finance  innovation  on  the  required 
scale.   
 
5. 
Venture  capital  investment  in  clean  technology.  Venture  capital  is  one  form  of 
financing  that  could  play  a  vital  role  in  meeting  this  need  for  investment.  According  to  the 
Cleantech  Group  and  Deloitte,  clean  technology  venture  capital  investment  in  North  America, 
Europe, India, and the People’s Republic of China (PRC) reached $7.77 billion in 2010, a 28% 
increase from  2009,  despite the  economic  slowdown  and absence  of  a global  climate  change 
accord to replace the Kyoto Protocol. Further, Dow Jones VentureSource found that about 20% 
of  all  venture  capital  investment  went  to  cleantech  in  2010—more  than  any  other  category, 
including  software  and  biotechnology.  With  venture  capital  on  the  rise,  the  sector  will  likely 
witness an upturn in initial public offerings (IPOs) and mergers and acquisitions in coming years. 
Despite  these  promising  signs,  Asia  and  the  Pacific  still  lags  North  America  and  Europe  in 
accessing  venture  capital  for  climatech.  Together,  the  PRC  and  India  accounted  for 
approximately 10% of total venture capital investment in clean technology in 2010, while North 
America and Europe continue to attract the vast majority of venture capital.

7. 
ADB technical assistance through the initiative. In addition to the equity investments, 
the initiative is expected to establish a capacity development TA facility, for which separate ADB 
Board  approval  will  be  sought  by  the  Regional  and  Sustainable  Development  Department 
(RSDD). The purpose of the proposed TA is for ADB’s DMCs to develop subsectors within their 
climatech  industries  that  need  support  in  attracting  more  active  participation  of  the  fund 
managers.  Specifically, the TA will retain a pool of experts to provide advice as requested on 
various  aspects  of  the  technology  development  cycle  (e.g.,  research  and  development, 
production,  intellectual  property  rights)  especially  in  subsectors  within  the  climatech  industry 
where  ADB’s  DMCs  may  not  have  active  participation  of  fund  managers  or  where  those  fund 
manager  have  less  direct  experience.  These  experts,  available  on  demand,  are  expected  to 
provide  support18  in  identifying  potential  investees  and  evaluating  new  technologies  and 
subsectors.    The TA  will  coordinate with  the  regional  departments  of  ADB  to identify  potential 
large scale deployment opportunities for promising climatech applications. 
 
8. 
By embracing the ingenuity of the private sector in developing low-carbon technologies 
and products that might not otherwise make it to the market, ADB believes that the  initiative—
with  its  equity  and  knowledge  components—can  help  the  DMCs  address  a  number  of  severe 
public  problems,  such  as  climate  change,  environmental  degradation,  energy  security,  and 
pollution-related health concerns. In the process, these efforts could offer a boost to a possible 
growth  sector,  thereby  creating  employment  opportunities,  reducing  poverty,  and  spurring 
economic growth. 
 
B. 

Investment Environment and Government Policy  

9. 
Regulatory  status.  The  three  funds  proposed  for  investment  will  primarily  target  the 
markets of the PRC and India, both of which are environments conducive to allowing the growth 
and success of climatech venture capital. The attractiveness of the investment environment for 
venture  capital  funds  in  these  countries  depends  on  several  key  factors.  The  first  is  the 
institutional  environment  for  business  development  and  venture  capital  fund  operations,  which 
determines  the  ease  with  which  businesses  can  start  up  and  access  essential  goods  and 
services,  and  the  ease  with  which  venture  capital  fund  operations  can  be  carried  out.  The 
second  is  the  market  conditions  in  the  sectors  targeted  by  the  venture  capital  funds,  which 
include  technology  demand  and  market  size,  and  which,  to  a  large  degree,  determine  growth 
potential  in  key  sectors.  The  third  is  the  climatech  policy  environment,  which  is  important  in 
creating  incentives  to  invest  in  climatech,  and  markets  for  climatech  products.  Because  the 
sector deals frequently with new technologies, climatech will frequently have a higher risk profile

$600 million.

three being proposed for investment at this time. Indeed, the selected fund managers already have the basic skills

proposed in this equity investment have gaps in climatech sector expertise, the fund managers may avail of the TA.

People’s  Republic  of  China.  The  opportunity  for  climatech  industries  in  the  PRC  is 
10. 
substantial,  supported  by  a  long-term  government  policy  commitment  to  the  promotion  of 
investment in the development and wider diffusion of climatech. The 12th Five Year Plan (2011–
2015)  adopts  a  target  for  the  reduction  of  the  energy  intensity  of  gross  domestic  product  of 
40%–45% from 2005 by 2020. Various sectoral and local legislative, investment incentive, and 
regulatory  programs  support  these  high-level  plans.  Mandatory  energy  efficiency  standards 
have been introduced for a range of appliances such as air conditioners, refrigerators, computer 
displays,  and  washing  machines.  Building  energy  efficiency  standards  and  incentives  for  the 
purchase  and  supply  of  green  building  materials  have  been  adopted.  In  the  transport  sector, 
more fuel-efficient vehicles enjoy preferential tax rates, and the purchase of electric and hybrid 
vehicles in some municipalities is subsidized. Renewable energy technologies enjoy a range of 
incentives,  including  substantial  feed-in-tariffs,  mandatory  connection  and  off-take  regulations 
for utility companies, subsidies for the purchase of off-grid renewable technologies, tax relief on 
renewable  investments,  and  interest-free  loans  for  eligible  projects.  In  addition,  decreases  in 
subsidies  for  fossil  fuels  and  increases  in  end-user  energy  prices  should  support  demand  for 
energy-efficient  products.  Water  sector  policy  initiatives  have  similarly  mandated  increases  in 
resource  use  efficiency.  Supportive  legislative  changes  have  strengthened  pollution  controls 
and  adopted  fees  for  wastewater  discharge,  as  well  as  concessional  loans  for  wastewater 
treatment projects.  
 
Research  and  development  in  climatech,  including  technologies  in  energy  efficiency, 
11. 
environmental  protection,  new  energy,  biotechnology,  new  materials,  and  clean-energy 
vehicles,  will  be  pursued  through  the  12th  Five  Year  Plan  via  a  number  of  tax  breaks  for 
research  and  development.  While  restrictions  on  capital  flows,  sectoral  restrictions  on 
investment, and sometimes bureaucratic and unpredictable administrative procedures do pose 
challenges  for  venture  capital  fund  operations,  they  are  likely  to  be  manageable.  Increasing 
liberalization  of  markets  and  rapid  development  of  capital  markets  are  likely  to  facilitate 
climatech venture capital fund exits through initial public offerings (IPOs) and third-party sales.  
 
India. India has adopted a range of long-term policy supports for climatech. Building on 
12. 
the  targets  for  the  11th  Five  Year  Plan  (2007–2012),  the  National  Action  Plan  on  Climate 
Change outlines legislative and investment programs, including the National Solar Mission, the 
National Mission for Enhanced Energy Efficiency, the National Mission on Sustainable Habitat, 
and  the  National  Water  Mission.  More  specifically,  in  support  of  sectoral  programs  for 
agriculture, households, and buildings, energy efficiency has been promoted by the introduction 
of  appliance  and  labeling  standards  for  a  range  of  items,  such  as  pumps,  motors,  air 
conditioners,  and  buildings  above  a  certain  size.  Renewable  energy,  and  in  particular  solar 
renewables,  is  promoted  through  a  range  of  aggressive  measures,  including  feed-in-tariffs; 
mandatory  renewables  quotas;  and  connection  requirements  for  utilities,  tradable  renewable 
certificates  for  utilities,  direct  subsidies,  concessional  loans  and  tax  breaks  for  renewables

C. 

Alignment with ADB Strategy and Operations  

13. 
The CFP and the selection of funds through it are broadly aligned with ADB’s Strategy 
2020  and  climate  change  priorities,  as  well  as  the  energy  sector  strategies  of  ADB  and  the 
DMCs targeted by the three proposed funds.   
 

1. 

Consistency with Strategy 2020 

14. 
The funds selected through the CFP will make venture capital investments in climatech 
companies  and  projects  in  the  DMCs.  As  such,  these  fund  investments  are  fully  aligned  with 
ADB’s Strategy 2020, which has enshrined environment, including climate change, as one of its 
five  core  operational  priorities.  Strategy  2020  notes  that  ―only  growth  that  is  environmentally 
sustainable can eliminate poverty,‖ and states:

Unless approaches to economic growth are altered to address pollution, the destruction 
of  natural  resources,  and  environmental  degradation  (including  climate  change),  the 
region’s  prospects 
jeopardy. 
Environmental  damage  and  resource  depletion  from  fast  growth  are  already  impeding 
the  region’s  development  and  reducing  the  quality  of  life—with  the  poor  most  severely 
affected. The Asian energy sector’s share of global carbon dioxide emissions have more 
than tripled from about 8% in 1980 to about 28% in 2005 (Appendix 1). The International 
Energy  Agency  forecasts  that  the  region’s  energy  demand  will  double  by  2015.  The 
region  has  the  highest  air  pollution  levels  in  the  world,  despite  slight  improvements  in 
some cities. Without greater efforts to safeguard the environment, pressure will continue 
to build on the region’s land, forests, water systems, wetlands, marine ecosystems, and 
other natural resources upon which many of the poor depend for their livelihoods. Urban 
centers will also suffer—the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development 
reports that 8 of the 10 coastal cities at the greatest long-term risk from climate change 
and rising sea levels are in Asia.20 

 
15. 
The  objective  of  the  climatech  investments  made  by  the  three  proposed  funds  is  to 
address climate change and the environment through development and transfer of technologies, 
which  aligns  well  with  Strategy  2020’s  promotion  of 
the  use  of  environment-friendly 
technologies,  and  its  focus  on  ―transfer  of  knowledge  and  technologies  on  environmental 
management.‖ 
 

2. 

Consistency with ADB’s Climate Change Priorities   

The  initiative  is  proposed  to  be  implemented  as  part  of  ADB's  recent  emphasis  on 
16. 
climatech  technology  transfer  and  diffusion,  one  of  the  identified  key  building  blocks  under 
international climate change negotiations, to help address energy security and climate change 
in  Asia  and  the  Pacific.  Such  efforts  regarding  technology  were  strongly  backed  by  the 
President's  Advisory  Group  on  Climate  Change  and  Sustainable  Development  in  its  first 
meeting  on  1  September  2009.  The  advisory  group,  in  its  subsequent  meeting  on  2  February 
2010, again emphasized ADB's potential catalytic role and urged ADB to help the region shift to 
new and improved technologies and move "from the abstract to the concrete."

17. 
ADB's  realigned  strategic  agenda  surrounding  climate  change,  embodied  in  the 
Addressing Climate Change in Asia and the Pacific: Priorities for Action paper approved by the 
President  on  27  April  2010,  specifically  states  that  ADB  will  move upstream  in the  technology 
development process, in collaboration with governments, venture funds, and other partners, to 
facilitate  the  introduction  of  new  clean  energy  technologies.  Innovative  financing,  especially 
through  public–private  partnerships,  will  be  extended  to  address  climate  change  adaptation 
needs. Because projects that employ new technologies often carry higher risks, ADB recognizes 
the need to extend incentives for the public and private sectors to invest in such projects. The 
paper elaborates that as a part of this process, ADB will review how it assesses its own project 
risks  and  determine  whether  adjustments  can  be  made  to  increase  support  for  technological 
innovations in the climate change field. 

3. 

Consistency with the Sector and Country Strategies 

18. 
Although clean energy is only one subsector within the broader area of climatech, it is a 
large  and  important  subsector,  comprising,  among  other  things,  renewable  energy,  energy 
efficiency, and clean technology. The investments in the three proposed funds are aligned with 
ADB’s Energy Policy (2009), which seeks to facilitate a transition to a low-carbon economy and 
universal access to energy as an important step toward achieving ADB’s vision of a region free 
of poverty.21 The objective of the Energy Policy is to help DMCs provide reliable, adequate, and 
affordable  energy  for  inclusive  growth  in  a  socially,  economically,  and  environmentally 
sustainable way.  It  emphasizes energy  efficiency  and renewable energy;  access to energy for 
all;  and  energy  sector  reforms,  capacity-building,  and  governance.  The  particular  country 
partnership  strategies  (CPSs)  for  various  DMCs  (including  the  PRC  and  India,  the  two  main 
target DMCs for the three proposed funds) echo the themes of the Energy Policy, setting targets 
for  more  environment-friendly  energy  mixes  to  improve  energy  security  and  ensure  the 
sustainability of economic progress.22,23  

 
To  achieve  these  objectives,  policy  implementation  will  be  based  in  part  on  private 
19. 
sector  participation  (and  public–private  partnerships)  to  improve  energy  sector  efficiency 
through  competition  and  an  increase  in  investable  resources  in  DMCs.  ADB  and  other 
multilateral development organizations have poured capital into this sector through public sector 
loans  and  other  financing  mechanisms  for  clean  energy  and  clean  technology.  However,  the 
investment  has  been  insufficient  to  build  and  sustain  the  increasingly  energy-intensive

22  In  its  CPS,  the  PRC  recognizes  the  need  to  improve  its  energy  efficiency  and  redefine  its  energy  mix  toward  a 
more environment-friendly combination. The country’s goals, as outlined in the CPS, include (i) ensuring resource 
efficiency and environmental sustainability by adopting clean and efficient energy, among other important sector-
specific platforms; and (ii) creating an enabling environment for private sector development through private sector 
financing  and  other  interventions  needed  to  increase  private  sector  participation  in  the  country’s  development 
activities. The CPS emphasizes that increasing private sector involvement would address certain funding gaps and 
investment  needs  in  the  country,  and  would  complement  the  (relatively  limited)  public  sector  funds  dedicated  to 
infrastructure, including clean energy. 

23  India's  CPS  for  2009–2012  emphasizes  the  urgent  need  to  carry  out  energy  infrastructure  projects  to  meet  the 
power  requirements  of  the  next  decades.  At  present,  rural  household  electrification  is  still  at  about  only  33% 
coverage, and the quality of power remains poor due to "(i) insufficient power generation capacities in these areas, 
(ii)  lack  of  optimum  utilization  of  the  generation  capacity,  (iii)  an  inadequate  and  aging  sub-transmission  and 
distribution network, (iv) large-scale theft and a skewed tariff structure, (v) the slow pace of rural electrification, and 
(vi)  inefficient  use  of  electricity  by  the  consumers."  These  challenges  are  seen  to  plague  the  country's  energy 
security  and  the  sustainability  of  economic  progress.  Thus,  together  with  ADB,  India  has  established  an  energy 
sector  results  framework  within  its  strategy  and  developed  ambitious  overall  target  outcomes,  such  as  (i)  the 
addition  of  at  least  70  megawatts  of  solar  power  generation,  (ii)  the  addition  of  at  least  982  megawatts  of 
hydropower  generation,  and  (iii)  the  building  of  an  efficient  power  transmission  network.  The  strategy 
acknowledges  the  importance  of  a  greater  role  for  the  private  sector  in  realizing  these  goals  through  funding  of 
some of the needed infrastructure.

4. 

Lessons from Previous Operations 

20. 
Incubating funds takes time and effort. ADB has learned from experience investing in 
clean  energy  funds.  In  2008,  ADB  approved  investments  in  five  clean  energy  funds,  selected 
through  a  CFP,  four  of  which  are  operating.  One  of  the  five  funds  withdrew  from  the  market 
entirely due to ongoing fundraising difficulties, while two others took over 2 years of fundraising 
to reach a first closing. This was due to the financial crisis prevailing since mid-2008, and in part 
to the basic challenges facing many first-time emerging markets fund managers. ADB provided 
extended  assistance  to  these  funds  over  2  years  in  incubation  activities  and  fundraising; 
because  the  funds  faced  many  challenges,  ADB’s  consistent  commitment  and  support  was 
critical  to  their  ultimate  success  in  reaching  financial  closure.  The  lesson  drawn  from  this 
experience  was  that  a  great  deal  of  time  and  effort  is  needed  to  incubate  first-time  emerging 
markets  funds  in  an  ongoing  challenging  fundraising  environment,  and  ADB  should  make  a 
deliberate choice regarding projects where this expenditure of time and effort is warranted.   
 
21. 
In  entering  new  markets  or  asset  classes,  established  managers  are  safer 
partners. Because it drew such a large volume of proposals, the CFP provided ADB the luxury 
of choice among established climatech venture capital fund managers in the PRC and India. As 
a  way  to  mitigate  the  risk  associated  with  an  asset  class  that  is  both  relatively  risky  and 
relatively  new  for  ADB,  ADB  selected  three  of  the  highest  caliber  and  most-experienced  fund 
managers  that  submitted  proposals.  None  of  the  three  is  a  first-time  manager,  and  all  three 
have successfully raised funds (for two of the three managers, multiple funds). Two of the three 
funds are well along in the fundraising process, and all three have established track records in 
climatech investing. These three managers are seen as the most commercially viable managers 
available  in  the  market  at  this  time,  and  this  is  viewed  as  an  appropriate  starting  point  for 
gaining exposure to a relatively new asset class.24  

                                                
24  Incubation of new funds is an appropriate role for ADB to play in circumstances where, for example, ADB wants to 
help develop a new asset class in which few managers exist and ADB does not have the luxury of choice among 
established  managers.  This  was  the case  for  this  CFP  with  regard  to particular  geographies, such  as  Southeast 
Asia; in these regions, ADB may choose to incubate a climatech fund.
